prompt.p: Two major genes have been implicated in neoplasia: oncogenes and tumour suppressor genes. These occur through mutations, chromosome translocation or viral activation.
What disease is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome?

modalFeedback.p:
Option A (Chronic myeloid leukaemia) is Correct. Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) is an uncommon clonal stem cell disorder making up 15% of all leukaemias. Presentation is more common in adults between the ages of 40 and 60 years. CML is characterized by a high white cell count, of granulocytic lineage, and the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (Ph).
Option B (Haemophilia B) is Incorrect. Mutation of factor IX gene is associated with haemophilia B.
Option C (Hodgkin's lymphoma) is Incorrect. The cause of Hodgkin's lymphoma is unknown, but it is possibly the result of Epstein–Barr virus infection.
Option D (Myelofibrosis) is Incorrect. Chronic myeloid leukaemia is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome.
Option E (Polycythaemia) is Incorrect. The cause of polycythaemia is unknown.
